Dr. Pradeep Tomar is working as Assistant Professor in the School of Information and Communication Technology, Gautam Buddha University, Greater Noida, U.P., India since 2009. Dr. Tomar earned his Ph.D. from MDU, Rohtak, Haryana, India. Before joining Gautam Buddha University, he worked as a Software Engineer in a multi-national company, Noida and lecturer in M. D. University, Rohtak, Haryana and Kurukshetra University, Kurukshetra, Haryana. Dr. Tomar has excellent teaching, research and software development experience as well as vast administrative experience at university level on various posts like HoD-Computer Science and Engineering, Chairperson-Admission, Vice Chairperson-Admissions, Research Coordinator, Examination Coordinator, University Coordinator, Admission, Time Table Coordinator, Proctor and Hostel Warden. He is also a member of Computer Society of India (CSI), Indian Society for Technical Education (ISTE), Indian Science Congress Association (ISCA), International Association of Computer Science and Information Technology (IACSIT) and International Association of Engineers (IAENG). He qualified the National Eligibility Test (NET) for Lecturership in Computer Applications in 2003, Microsoft Certified Professional (MCP) in 2008, SUN Certified Java Programmer (SCJP) for the Java platform, standard edition 5.0 in 2008 and qualified the IBM Certified Database Associate - DB2 9 Fundamentals in 2010.


Dr. Tomar was awarded Bharat Jyoti Award by India International Friendship Society in the field of Technology in 2012 and Bharat Vikas Award by Institute of Self Reliance in National Seminar on Diversity of Cultural and Social Environment at Bhubaneswar, Odisha, in 2017. He has been awarded for the Best Computer Faculty award by Govt. of Pondicherry and ASDF society. His biography is published in Whoâ€™s Who Reference Asia, Volume II. Dr. Tomar has been awarded distinguished Research Award from Institute for Global Business Research for his work in "A Web-Based Stock Selection Decision Support System for Investment Portfolio Management in 2018. He delivered expert talks at FDP, workshops, national and international conferences. He has organized three conferences: one national conference with COMMUNE group and two international conferences, in which one international ICIAICT 2012 was organized by CSI, Noida Chapter and second international conference 2012 EPPICTM was organized in collaboration with MTMI, USA, University of Maryland Eastern Shore, USA and Frostburg State University, USA at School of Information and Communication Technology, Gautam Buddha University, Greater Noida, India.


Apart from teaching, he is running a programming club for ICT students and he is guiding various research scholars in the areas of software engineering, reusability of code, soft computing technique, Big Data, and IoT. His major current research interest is in Component-Based Software Engineering. He is working as Co-investigator in a sponsored research project in High throughput design, synthesis and validation of TALENs for targeted Genome Engineering, funded by Department of Biotechnology, Ministry of Science and Technology Government of India. Two books â€œTeaching of Mathematicsâ€ and â€œCommunication and Information Technologyâ€ at national levels, three books â€œExamining Cloud Computing Technologies through the Internet of Things (IoT)â€, â€œHandbook of Research on Big Data and the IoTâ€, â€œGreen and Smart Technologies for Smart Citiesâ€ at international level are authored and edited by Dr. Tomar. He has also contributed more than 100 papers/articles in national/international journals and conferences. He served as a member of the editorial board and reviewer for various Journals and national/international conferences.

SOFTWARE ENGINEERING
Development of Conceptualization based Indexing Scheme for Semantic Web Search Engine.
During the last two decades internet and web became vehicles of sharing and using a large variety of web resources. Due to the widespread availability of its usage, it has become an indispensable tool. A plethora of information floods through the web every second. Present web consisting of HTML documents only display its contents, without understanding human intention so unable to find out context of word used. If the user enters a synonym of a word in the search box, keyword based search engine fails to retrieve actually required information desired by the user. Due to lack of semantics, web pages are unable to interpret the meaning and machine is unable to understand searcher intention. In this work, Sem-Modelhas been proposed to address the problems with these current indexing schemes. In this research work, to retrieve relevant information framework for extracting and visualizing semantic knowledge has been designed in which concept and relations among entities are extracted automatically to develop ontology representing facts and knowledge which helps in understanding userâ€™s need to retrieve relevant information. Ontology learning and Sentiment analysis is carried out on the dataset of tweets available using big data platform. The studies reflect the userâ€™s behavioural responses on a particular topic. To create semantic knowledge representation, semantic annotation has been done and documents are retrieved by matching the semantic description of user query with annotated documents. The document search is performed by Semantically Extended Query Module. It matches the semantic description of user query with its counterparts in annotated documents. This work has focus on improving effective information obtaining mechanism using more effective inference mechanism for finding similar concepts to given query so that better Precision and Recall has been achieved. Keyword search engines are unable to understand the intention of user as a result they produce enormous results for user to distinguish between relevant and non relevant answers of user queries. This has led to rise in requirement to work search capabilities of different search engines. In this research work, experimental evaluation is done based on different metrics to distinguish different search engines on the basis of type of query that can be handled by them. The experimental results demonstrate that for single term query, Google retrieves more relevant documents and DuckDuckGo retrieves more relevant documents for NLP queries. 

Component Based Software Quality Prediction Using Soft Computing Techniques
In todayâ€™s technological world the Component-Based Software System is applied in various fields of engineering, to ease their multitasking function. In Component-Based Software Engineering, the software functions are created as components, it can reuse for different purpose. So, the quality of these software component should ensure, before implementation. In the beginning the techniques such as ISO 9126, Bertoa, ISO 25010, CBQM and Alvaro model are utilized to analysis the quality of software. The prediction performance of these quality measures is not up to the mark with conventional approaches, hence this work motivated to develop a soft computing-based prediction approach for the software quality prediction. This work proposed four different approaches for the software quality prediction. In the first approach an improved particle swarm optimization based neural network is presented for the prediction of software quality. The IPSO proposed to tune the neural network based on the reliability value. Then to enhance the prediction performance the second approach proposed an optimal fuzzy classifier based with evolutionary programming. The evolutionary programming is used for the optimal fuzzy rule selection, so that the decision accuracy of fuzzy can enhance. In comparison with the previous IPSO, the optimal fuzzy classifier provided better prediction performance such as reliability and maintainability. In the third approach, a hybrid cuckoo search based advanced neural network is presented for the software quality prediction. In this approach the HCS used to tune the neural network, and to enhance the performance of ANN. The proposed approach is compared with the previous IPSO and evolutionary programming. Among them the HCS based quality prediction provided better performance. In the last approach a novel teaching-learning optimization based artificial neural network is proposed for the effective prediction of software quality in CBS system. The proposed TLO employed in the training phase of ANN for the weight optimization. The proposed TLO based prediction technique outperforms the previous techniques. Ultimately the motivated objective is achieved by the execution of four consecutive software quality prediction approaches. The overall performance of the final TLO based software quality prediction provides better performance than the other techniques. Hence the proposed work suggested that the soft computing based is the better option for the software quality prediction. 

Dynamic Metrics Measurement for Component-Based Software Engineering
Software metrics are concerned with various changes in requirements of software and its development. These requirements are useful for the quality assurance in Component-Based Software (CBS) and measure the behaviour of interfaces of components through which these components interact with each other. This work focuses on dynamic measurement of CBS. This work analyzes the run time behavior of CBS to measure it dynamically. In order to incorporate changes in software components at run time, it is required to analyze the dependencies among the components. This work has proposed a function which is used in software components integration. The proposed function first validates the properties of components by passing some parameters and then calculates its usability factor. The dependency function helps to find out the component usability when the components need to be integrated to get the required functionality at the time of execution. The proposed dynamic metric called Component Usability Metric (CUM) calculates its dependency factors based on the parametric values for the components. The dependency function helps to find out the Component Usability Factor (CUF) when the components are integrated to get the required functionality of that component during the execution. This metric will help to identify the functionality level of a component within the integrated software system. Another proposed component metric called Component Interface Metric (CIM) is also used to measure the interface complexity of the CBS. This proposed metric is measured with the help of CUM. These dynamic metrics are used to improve the performance of JEE application to evaluate the quality of a real-time system with the help of NGET Application of Indian railway. The quality characteristics of CBS are assessed through CUM dynamic metric.

Software Quality Prediction for Component Based Software Using Computational Intelligence
Software Quality means the stakeholder satisfaction. It includes both - the consumer and the producer of the software system. Software Quality Assurance (SQA) means the meeting of the stakeholderâ€™s requirements in a particular environment. There are so many SQA models are present like- McCall model, ISO/IEC-9126 model etc. During last few years, a new field called Computational Intelligence had emerged as an excellent tool for solving a vast variety of problems and to support the various engineering techniques. The literature has shown itâ€™s overwhelming applications in an area of SQA. This work is an exploration and exploitation of computational and non-computational based techniques in the domain of SQA. The researcher are using CI techniques for the assessment of individual quality characteristics only but this work shows that the SQA is a combinatorial problem which depends upon a number of quality characteristics. This work given an optimal mathematical model for the assessment of degree of stakeholder satisfaction (Q) by predicting the different quality attributes like reliability, reusability etc. at a common extent of time in a combined form. The experimental with case work shows that the mathematical model for SQA is an optimal model for the calculation of Q. SQA team can generate the minimum and maximum values of Q with the help of the proposed optimal model. New optimization algorithms like Improved-Ant Colony Optimization (I-ACO) algorithm, Hybrid Cuckoo-ACO algorithm and Visualization power optimization algorithm also been introduced in this work for the assessment of the quality characteristics. 

Reliability Prediction for Component-Based Software by using Soft Computing Techniques
The reliability assessment of software system has always been a thrust area for the software engineering researchers. The reliability prediction becomes easier if important factors and relationship between factors affecting reliability are identified. Identification and assessment of these factors to develop a reliable system is a difficult task. This work identified the CBS factors which are used for predicting the reliability of CBS. This work proposed Component-Based Software Reliability Model by identifying the CBS factors like complexity, failure, component dependency, reusability, and component interaction etc. But, to design and develop an efficient reliability model, many techniques have been used by researchers and practitioners to predict and estimate the reliability of CBS. However, the soft computing techniques have become very popular due to finding the optimized result of a given problem. This work assesses the various soft computing techniques which are necessary to predict the reliability of CBS. Few CBSE metrics have also been applied to assess the soft computing techniques like ACO, PSO, and ABC to develop CBS reliability model. On the basis of assessment of soft computing techniques, it is found that PSO and fuzzy approaches are more capable of predicting the CBS reliability. To predict the reliability of CBS, fuzzy and PSO techniques are adopted to evaluate the proposed model. The proposed model is capable of predicting the reliability and performance of CBS using soft computing techniques. The verification and validation of CBSRM are performed using MATLAB with Quality of Web Service data-sets to observe the results of the proposed model.

Analysis and Evaluation of ECG Signal for Emotion Recognition using Computational Intelligence
In this work, a computational system has been designed for recognition of emotional states i.e. calm, stress and anger by analyzing ECG morphological features pattern.For validation of this research, an authentic ECG real-time data of 17 drivers is used which was acquired in emotion simulated pathways. A system for emotion recognition based on extraction of ECG pattern features i.e. QRS, P wave and ST segment is designed. This system also includes preprocessing of ECG signals which increase the accuracy of emotional recognition system. This work is divided into three phases: In first phase, a wavelet based PRFB denoising system is designed for preprocessing and de-noising of ECG signal which eradicates unwanted artifacts and helps to extract features properly. After denoising, second phase includes feature extraction of ECG waveform by Multi Resolution Analysis (MRA) of wavelet with data flow modeling. Three features i.e. QRS complex, P wave and ST segment of ECG signal were extracted as these features were affected by different emotional states. Till now, nobody used these features to calculate the emotions of human. The novelty lies in the fact that, all the three emotional states i.e. stress, calm and anger are recognized by using only these three features which ultimately reduces the complexity of the overall system. Further, these features have been validated by using statistical analysis with an accuracy rate i.e. Confidence Interval (CI) of 95 %. In the third phase of this work, a computational based Mamdani fuzzy system has been developed which computationally examines the different features and determine the emotional states i.e. calm, anger and stress. This proposed fuzzy system has been validated by different cardiologists and mathematically by designing confusion matrix. The proposed system outperforms the conventional systems in terms of accuracy, less complexity and less confusion rate. The accuracy rate of proposed system is 92% with an improvement of 30% in correlation analysis.

Design and Evaluation of Software Testing Technique using Computational Intelligence
About 40-50 % cost of SDLC is spent on software testing; this shows that testing is an expensive process which further gets incremented if it is performed manually. Therefore researchers and practitioners try to reduce the cost of software testing by replacing the manual software testing process by automation. As testing itself has many techniques and three essential costly sub-techniques are â€œAutomatic Test Case Generation (ATCG), Test Case Prioritization (TCP), and Test Case Optimization.â€ Unfortunately, these are performed manually with little automation success rate. Therefore, to reduce the cost of software testing, the success of these sub-techniques is very essential. During last few years, a new field called computational intelligence had emerged as an excellent tool for solving a vast variety of problems. The literature has shown itâ€™s overwhelm application is an area of software testing. This work is an exploration and exploitation of computational and non-computational based techniques in the domain of software testing techniques - ATCG, TCP and Test Case Optimization. For addressing Test Case Optimization, a framework called Hybrid Test Language Processing (HTLP) is proposed. The methodology used in HTLP is based on keyword-oriented data-driven approach called Test Language Processing (TLP) that can be used for both Web and Graphic User Interface (GUI) based applications. The Test Case Optimization is performed by executing the proposed framework on an open source web application. With the successful execution of framework, it is concluded that 83.78 % of Test Suite Optimization is achieved along with thoroughly tested System Under Test (SUT) which is not possible with the manual approach in time bound environment. To address ATCG, a Path-Specific Target (PST) data generation approach is proposed and experimented with several problems. Three computational intelligence based metaheuristic namely Genetic Algorithm (GA), Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Artificial Bee Colony Optimization 

Design and Evaluation of Software Component Selection Algorithm according to Requirements using Fuzzy Clustering Techniques
Component-Based Software Development (CBSD) achieves software reusability by creating software systems from the current software rather than building from scratch. This work is motivated by four main research objectives: firstly, to develop a component selection process based on clustering, secondly to design and develop a component selection algorithm for it. The third objective is about analyzing and evaluating the performance and complexity of the component selection algorithm. The fourth objective is about the verification and validation of the complete component selection process and algorithm. This work firstly proposes a component selection process with the help of four-tier architecture to select optimal component using clustering. Secondly, it designs and evaluates a fuzzy relation-based fuzzy clustering algorithm for component selection. Finally, the time complexity and performance of the algorithm is calculated and compared with the standard algorithms. According to the fourth objective the verification of the component selection algorithm is carried out by confirming the correctness of each step of the algorithm before writing code for it. The algorithm is validated on a real dataset of components extracted from an online component repository. After verification and validation, the major findings of this work are: the use of clustering has reduced the search space and components are clustered based on multi-attributes rather than considering one or two attributes, as compared to built-in functions of Fuzzy c-means and subtractive clustering. The use of fuzzy clustering based on fuzzy relations has eased the task of selection as the tedious task of minimization or maximization of objective functions is eliminate. This dependency of clustering results on the distance metric for similarity or dissimilarity is eliminated using the proposed FREFCOSCO (Fuzzy Relation-Based Fuzzy Clustering of Software Component) algorithm. The simple fuzzy clustering technique requires mentioning the number of cluster centers beforehand, in case of Fuzzy C-Means and the radii of the cluster in case of subtractive clustering. The performance of the algorithm, when implemented in Matrix Laboratory (MATLAB), is far better than the existing methods. The time complexity as compared to the standard methods is much better. It can be concluded that this work presents a high performance component selection algorithm based on functional and non-functional requirement with a very less computational time. This is supported with the help of the real life database of components taken from the online repository. 

Design and Evaluation of New Reusability Metrics Based on Fuzzy Approach to Measure the Quality of Component-Based Software
Component-Based Software Engineering (CBSE) supports the practice of building software from the pre-existing component or third party software Component-Off-The-Shelf (COTS). This work would help to manage the quality assurance by measuring reusability which is a significant attribute of software quality. This work helps in analysis, design, and development of reusability metrics to complete the demand of good reusable software components in the software industry. A reusability metrics for proper quantification of the quality characteristic reusability is proposed. This reusability metrics considers five factors: coupling, interface complexity, understandability, customizability, and reliability. The reliability factor is included in this metrics as this work found reliability as a major factor of quality in the literature review. The available literature does not give due importance to reliability in reusability measurement. Despite the growing research in the measurement of quality or some quality attributes of Component-Based Software (CBS), there are few models to automate the reusability measurement of the software component. To automate the reusability measurement of a CBS, a rule-based fuzzy approach is developed based on reusability metrics. For this approach, a set of rules is defined as a rule base. Using this approach, the reusability of a majority of software components can be measured. To test component reusability during interaction, this work proposes reusability metrics for web service components with different set of factors as the quality concern in web services is different. This work modified the factors of reusability metrics for web service component to meet the requirement. Five key factors, coupling, interface complexity, response time and reliability were identified for estimation of reusability in the context of web service components. The individual web service reusability is measured using proposed reusability metrics as well as the reusability of web services under interaction with other web services is also measured with this reusability metrics. The quality of a black box component depends on factors like complexity, reusability, maintainability, and reliability. An individual component quality also influences the overall quality of CBS. This work performed an evaluation of the effect of reusability on the quality of CBS. This was done empirically by examining the effect of reusability metrics attributes on software quality characteristics. 

Analysis, Design and Development of Component-Based Reusable Models and Testing Processes
In software engineering, development life cycle processes of any software include all activities of software during its entire life. Historically, traditional model of software development have focused primarily on the functionality of a software system. There are two main groups of models - sequential and evolutionary. The sequential model defines a sequence of activities in which one activity follow after a completion of the previous one. Evolutionary model allows performance of several activities in parallel without requirements on a stringent completion of one activity to be able to start with another one. Well known examples of sequential models are waterfall model and V model, and of evolutionary models are iterative and incremental development, and spiral model. This work proposes a new X model for Component-Based Development (CBD) which comes under the evolutionary model. X model is a complex multifaceted activity that involves several phases - software analysis and specifications, design, coding and archiving, component testing, component wrapping, domain analysis, domain engineering, frameworking, assembling, archiving and design of software components. Finally, X model appears to cover the likely phases of large software development and enforces software reusability along its phases with two processes â€“ development for reuse and development with reuse.

RESEARCH PROJECTS 
High throughput design, synthesis and validation of TALENs for targeted Genome Engineering, Department of Biotechnology, Ministry of Science and Technology Government of India New Delhi, India

Name of Funding Agency: Department of Biotechnology, Ministry of Science and Technology Government of India New Delhi, India. Grant Received: Rs 8628100/-

Team Members: Dr. Vikrant Nain (Principal Investigator) and Dr. Pradeep Tomar (Co- PI)

Project Description:
With the availability of meganuclease (ZFN, TALEN & CRISPR), tailored changes can be introduced into a eukaryotic genome at any desired gene. However, IPRs held by foreign organizations, high cost of synthesis and off target activity remain major constraints in adoption of this technology for commercial purpose. The proposed research project aims to develop material (synthetic gene sequences) and methods for robust high throughput custom designed TALEN synthesis. Further, methods will be developed for analysis of genome wide activity and specificity of newly developed TALENs, using next generation sequencing.

Dr. Pradeep Tomar

table.name: teacherdata
table.column: Dr. Bhupendra Chaudhary is an Assistant Professor of Plant Genetics and Biotechnology at Gautam Buddha University. He is a noted researcher whose current research interests lie in the evolutionary genetics of cotton fiber development which encompasses molecular and genome evolution, phylogenetics, and functional characterization of key gene families evolved under cotton domestication using transgenic technologies in cotton. Dr Chaudhary completed his M.Phil. and PhD. from the University of Delhi in 1999 and 2006, respectively. Chaudhary was a Postdoctoral and University Research Fellow at Iowa State University, USA from 2007-08. He has published more than forty research papers in the national and international peer-reviewed journals. Dr. Chaudhary is a keen student of social science policy particularly related to the field of agriculture.

2009 onwards              : Assistant Professor of Biotechnology, Gautam Buddha University, Greater Noida, U.P. 

2007- 2008                  : DBT Visiting Associate, Department of EEOB, Iowa State University, USA 

2005 - 2009                 : Assistant Professor of Botany, Visva-Bharati University, Santiniketan, W.B.

BtMSc 508 Genomics and Proteomics; M.Sc. Biotech., Sem. II BT514 Genomics and Proteomics Lab, Int. B.Tech.-M.Tech. Sem. VIII  BT510 Regulation Ethics and Patenting in Biotechnology, Int. B.Tech.-M.Tech. Sem. VIII

• Advanced Plant Biotechnology (03 Credits); M.Tech. Biotechnology (2 Years) Program; Sem. III
  • Advanced Plant Biotechnology Lab (02 Credits); M.Tech. Biotechnology (2 Years) Program; Sem. III
  • Life Sciences-I (02 Credits); Int. B.Tech-M.Tech. Biotechnology (5 Years) Program; Sem. I
  • Advanced Plant Biotechnology (03 Credits); Ph.D. Program
  • Research Methodology (03 Credits/shared); Ph.D. Program
  • Minor Project (05 Credits); 04 M.Tech. Students

Topic


My research investigates the genomics, and genetic engineering of crop plants for improved field traits and resistance to stress conditions. I am specifically interested in the development of genomic resources responsible for cotton fiber development and their impact on the future crop improvement strategies. Current work also explores the paracrine and long-distance hormonal activities of cytokinin in root-to-shoot communication that will be utilized in the development of transgenic mustard with enlarged root system exhibiting increased drought tolerance without having negative side effects in the aerial organs. I am most concerned with identifying novel genes and their functional aspects and engaging them in a sustainable and rewarding application in the field that improves the agricultural outcomes for the society. 

 

I welcome inquiries from Masters and PhD candidates interested in: Plant Functional Genomics, Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology of Crop Plants, In vitro Regeneration of Crop Plants, Gene Expression Dynamics, especially during cellular development/elongation; and in response to abiotic stresses. 

 

My current projects include:

 

Â·         Comparative Functional Genomics of Cotton Fiber Development

We had generated genomic resources and identified candidate genes important to fiber development and evolved under domestication, using a microarray platform that interrogates 42,429 unigenes. Interestingly, prolonged fiber growth in the domesticated cotton was associated with enhanced hormone signalling genes, delayed stress-responsive gene expression and modulation of cell-wall structural genes, such as profilin gene family. Currently, our research group is mainly focussing on- (1) spatio-temporal expression characterization of cotton profilins (GhPRFs) in fiber-cell metabolism by generating RNAi-transgenics and over-expressed profilin in fibers; and (2) target-mimicry based silencing of miR167 gene family for up-regulation of Auxin Response Factors (hormone-signalling) in cotton fibers. These objectives are certainly enhancing our basic knowledge of candidate genes considered to be important for cotton fiber elongation. Also, assigning functions to such genes, and analysis/processing of diverse genomic/geneic information are generating novel insights into genetic architecture of the key biological processes at system and function level.

 

Â·         Enhanced Drought Tolerance in Indian Oilseed Mustard  

This project focuses on the genetic transformation of Indian mustard Brassica juncea with the inhibition of cytokinin, a regulator of root growth in a root-specific manner that may contribute to improve drought tolerance by the formation of a larger root system; as well as increased nutrient efficiency of transgenic mustard plants. This establishes an approach for modulating root system architecture that will be useful for generating crop plants optimized to grow in difficult agricultural environments. This also increases our understanding of the paracrine and long-distance hormonal activities of cytokinin in root-to-shoot communication.

 

Â·         Genetics of in vitro Regeneration in Cotton

A prerequisite to the development of genetic transformation in any crop is the availability of a regeneration system. In cotton, in vitro regeneration from hypocotyl and cotyledonary explants has been reported to follow somatic embryogenesis pathway, and is highly genotype dependent. And, there are strong basis for a genetic control of regeneration through embryogenesis in cotton. Inheritance of in vitro regeneration traits is being followed by crossing of fully-regenerating (FR) and non-regenerating (NR) near-isogenic lines (NILs) in hybrid and segregating populations. This project also has implications for the development of pure lines of regeneration trait into elite Indian cotton cultivars. These fully-regenerating lines will be highly beneficial for gene stacking by introducing more economically important genes directly to Indian varieties, without failure.

Topic

Research Area: Respiratory Medicine (Pulmonary Emphysema)

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a progressive life threatening lung disease that causes breathlessness and predisposes to exacerbation and serious illness. COPD was anticipated to be the fourth most important reason of demise, globally. COPD has been ranked 11th in chronic morbidity in 2002 and is estimated to rise to 7th position by 2030. There are two major diseases that lie under COPD, i.e. pulmonary bronchitis and pulmonary emphysema. Pulmonary emphysema characterized by alveolar wall destruction is resultant of persistent chronic inflammation. Recently only, growth factors like kerotinocyte growth factor (KGF) and hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) and derivative of vitamin-A that is all-trans retinoic acid have been reported to reverse emphysema in rodent models. However, the underlying molecular mechanisms behind the progression of emphysema disease and therapeutic potential of growth factors and ATRA in tissue regeneration are so far unknown. Hence, my research is interested in identifying all those various molecular pathways which plays important role in: 1) progression of pulmonary emphysema and 2) alveolar tissue regeneration. I believe in that, such recovery of lost alveolar septa tissue may raise a possibility to treat patients of emphysema in future.

table.column:
Dr. Navin Kumar, PhD                                               

Dr. Navin Kumar is an Assistant Professor in the School of Biotechnology at Gautam Budhha University, Greater Noida, India. He obtained his graduation (Zoology, Botany, and Chemistry) and post-graduation degree (Biotechnology) in 2003 from Chaudhary Charan Singh University, Meerut, India. He received his Ph.D. (2012) under the supervision of Prof. Gauranga Mukhopadhyay and Prof. Rakesh K. Tyagi from Special Centre for Molecular Medicine at Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, India. Since 2012-2016, he worked as a Postdoctoral Research Fellow with Prof. Jaya S. Tyagi in the Department of Biotechnology, All India Institute of Medical Sciences, New Delhi, India. He is working on host-pathogen interaction and Cag-type IV secretion system of Helicobacter pylori and published several papers in international refereed journals and in conferences at national and international platforms.

Educational Qualification:

Postdoctoral Research Fellow:           All India Institute of Medical Sciences, New Delhi, India.  

PhD in Molecular Medicine:               Special Centre for Molecular Medicine, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, India.

M.Sc. in Biotechnology:                     Department of Biotechnology, Ch. Charan Singh University, Meerut, UP, India.

Teaching/Research Experience

2016- till date: Assistant Professor, School of Biotechnology, Gautam Buddha University, (GBU) Greater Noida, U.P, India

2014- 2016:     Worked as a Young Scientist in Dept. of Biotechnology, All India Institute of Medical Sciences, New Delhi, India. 

2012- 2014:     Worked as a Research Associate (RA) in Dept. of Biotechnology, All India Institute of Medical Sciences, New Delhi.

2004 â€“ 2006:   Worked as a Junior Research Fellow (JRF), Special Centre for Molecular Medicine, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi.

Molecular Medicine
Medical Lab Technology
Animal Biotechnology
Animal Biotechnology and Plant Biotechnology
Advanced research Techniques
Stem Cell Biology
Life Science-Animal

Topic

Â·         Specialized secretion systems are versatile transporters in nature and widespread in the prokaryotes. Bacterial pathogen utilizes these secretion systems for virulence and survival. Patients with gastritis, ulcers and gastric carcinoma are often infected with H. pylori type I strains, which are characterized by the presence of cag-pathogenicity island (cag-PAI) that encodes type IV secretion system (TFSS). H. pyloriâ€™s type I strain, encoding active Cag-type IV secretion system (Cag-T4SS), was reported as a class I carcinogen by World Health Organization. Cag-T4SS is membranes spanning protein complexes having surface exposed pilus that transports â€˜oncoproteinâ€™ CagA into the host cell. Our lab is working to understand structural and function analysis of Helicobacter pylori type IV secretion system. Moreover, to unravel the survival strategies of Helicobacter pylori in human stomach.  

Â·         Host-Pathogen Interaction: The role of Vitamin C in host immune response against Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Previous study has reported the occurrence of Vitamin C deficiency in TB patients. Vitamin C triggers growth arrest of M.tb and promotes dormancy phenotype (INH drug tolerant population of M.tb) in both axenic culture and human macrophage cell line Therefore, further study will be necessary on many fronts to understand the effect of Vitamin C on M.tb in cell infection and animal models as well as human subjects to confront the challenge of TB including drug-resistant TB.

table.column: PhD(2010) Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) and International Centre for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology, New Delhi , India

Dr. Jitendra Singh Rathore is an Assistant Professor at School of Biotechnology, Gautam Buddha University, Uttar Pradesh, India. He is graduated from University of Delhi, followed by Masterâ€™s in Biotechnology (M.Sc Biotechnology) from Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Roorkee. Later, he completed Ph.D in Biotechnology from International Centre for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology (ICGEB, funded by United Nation) and School of Biotechnology, Jawaharlal Nehru University, (JNU) New Delhi, India.

He joined School of Biotechnology, Gautam Buddha University on 1st Sep 2009. He is recipient of prestigious Fulbright Postdoctoral fellowship from United States-India  Education Foundation (USIEF) under public health category and worked at Perelman School of Medicine, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, USA from 1st Sep 2013- 30 Aug 2014.

His area of research is molecular bacteriology, specifically to study the antimicrobial resistance development and persister cell formation in bacterium. He has also received two (02) extramural research grants from funding agencies including Science and Engineering Research Board- Department of Science and Technology (SERB-DST) New Delhi, Govt. of India and Council of Science and Industrial Research (CSIR) New Delhi, Govt. of India.

He has more than 10 years of teaching experience in different subjects of biotechnology including Introductory Bioinformatics, Microbiology, Vaccine Design and Development, Immunology and Recombinant DNA Technology. So far he has supervised 25 B.Tech-M.Tech students in their major dissertation projects and currently he is also supervising 04 Ph.D students. Apart from these, few of his students are selected for Ph.D program in International Institutes like Max Plank Institute of Chemical Ecology, Germany, University of Manchester, UK and Nankai University, China under Indo-China exchange program. Some of his students are also pursing Ph.D from leading Institute in India including IIT Delhi, IIT Guwahati and NIPGR (DBT Institute) New Delhi.

Topic

Bacterial Persistence & Host-Pathogen Interaction (Pulmonary Infection)

 

1. Bacterial Persistence: Toxin-antitoxin (TA) systems are small genetic elements found on plasmids or chromosomes of countless bacteria, archaea, and possibly also unicellular fungi. Under normal growth conditions, the activity of the toxin protein or its translation is counteracted by an antitoxin protein or non coding RNA. Five types of TA systems have been proposed that differ markedly in their genetic architectures and modes of activity control. Subtle regulatory properties, frequently responsive to environmental cues, impact the behavior of TA systems. Typically, stress conditions result in the degradation or depletion of the antitoxin. Unleashed toxin proteins impede or alter cellular processes including translation, DNA replication, or ATP or cell wall synthesis. TA toxin activity can then result in cell death or in the formation of drug-tolerant persister cells. The versatile properties of TA systems have also been exploited in biotechnology and may aid in combating infectious diseases.

 

2. Bacterial-Host Interaction (Pulmonary Infection Th17 response)

To perform its primary function of gas exchange, the mucosal surface of the lungs is continuously exposed to the environment. Given the considerable infection risk to the host, complex mechanism exists to prevent the development of bacterial infection. The immune system in the lungs consists of both innate and adaptive components, and it is clear these two systems are highly interdependent for optimal host defense. With the recent discovery of a distinct subset of Th cells called Th17 cells, in addition to the previously well characterized Th1- and Th2-cell subsets, came many new breakthroughs in the realm of innate and adaptive immunity. Th17 cells have been shown to differentiate from naÃ¯ve CD4+ cells in the presence of IL-6 and TGF-Î² in mice, or IL-6 and IL-1 in humans, when stimulated with appropriate antigen via activation of the transcription factor STAT3. As CD4+ cells commit to the effector Th17 phenotype, the hallmark cytokines IL-17A, IL-17F, IL-21, and IL-22 are expressed via STAT-3-dependent activation of the critical transcription factor retinoid-related orphan receptor Î³t. Th17 cells have been found to play a vital role in host defense against numerous pathogens. However, while Th17 cells are paramount in the adaptive phases of host defense, several other cell types are able to generate these cytokines in the earlier phases of immune response and bridge the gap between innate and adaptive immunity in the lung. These cell types include Î³Î´ T cells, natural killer (NK) cells, NKT cells, and certain innate lymphoid cells.

New vaccine approaches are needed against Streptococcus pneumoniae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Bacillus anthracis and Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which are the keys pathogenic bacteria responsible for serious pulmonary infections in developing countries like India. Although Th17 cells can protect against gram-negative pathogens at mucosal surfaces, including the lung, the bacterial proteins recognized by Th17 cells are largely unknown and could be potential new vaccine candidates. I am interested in the identification of Th17-stimulating antigens from Streptococcus pneumoniae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa , Bacillus anthracis and Mycobacterium tuberculosis, using ORFeomics approach, which can be used as serotype-independent novel vaccine candidates in future.

 

Technical expertise (key word): Genetic Engineering, Microbiology, Immunology, Bioinformatics, and Proteomics.

  •     Computational Biology  , M.Tech & Integrated B.Tech-M.Tech (Biotechnology) 
  •      Computational Biology Lab, Integrated B.Tech-M.Tech (Biotechnology) 
  •       Bioinformatics, M.Sc  (Biotechnology)

Topic

----->Area of Research:  Computational Biology, Pharmaceutical sciences, Proteomics. Focus area : Molecular modeling & Drug Design.
The ability to design drugs effectively depends on the fundamental understanding of the structures of molecules and the biochemical interaction networks. The past decade has witnessed a paradigm shift in drug discovery with structure-based drug design playing a crucial role. The gap between the number of identified hits and actual drug candidates can be bridged by investigating the underlying interactions. A pool of information combining crystallographic structures and molecular modeling techniques permits to predict receptor 3D models of good quality. These models serve as a basis to establish and validate efficient rationales used to screen virtual libraries for obtaining hits. The most significant contribution is employing an integrated approach combining structure based drug design, systems biology and biological circuits to help in gaining synergy in drug design.

 The role of these approaches with respect to two different classes of pharmaceutical targets has been studied.: (a) Plasmodium falciparum metalloaminopeptidases,  promising targets for anti-malarial drug development. (b) G-protein coupled receptor- particularly orphan GPCRs reported to be predominantly expressed in pancreatic Î² â€“cells and a plausible target for treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

GYANADITYA SHAKYA is a well known name in the field of PÄli language & literature. He is born as the son of Shri Ram Autar Shakya and Smt. Vimal Devi at village Manikpur in district Mainpuri near Sankasya, the holy land of Buddhism. Having completed his school education from Mainpuri, he did Bachelor of Arts from Dr. Bhimrao Ambedkar University, Agra and Master of Arts in Pali & Prakrit with Gold Medal from Rashtrasant Tukadoji Maharaj Nagpur University, Nagpur. He has cleared N.E.T. (National Eligibility Test) & J.R.F. (Junior Research Fellowship) in three subjects like Pali, Buddhist, Jaina, Gandhian & Peace Studies and Comparative Study of Religions. He completed his Master of Philosophy & Doctor of Philosophy under the supervision of Professor Bhikshu Satyapala from Department of Buddhist Studies, University of Delhi, Delhi. He is associated with PÄli Society of India as the founder member. His many articles & research papers have been published in different research journals & magazines; he is associated with many of them as a member of editorial board. He has also worked as editor and assistant editor in the different issues of the research journals like NibbÄna-Bodhi â€“ The Research Journal of Religion, Philosophy, Culture and Social Sciences (An International Peer Reviewed Refereed Research Journal) and Saá¹…gÄyana: The International Journal of Buddhist Studies. His thirteen research books like Bauddha Dharma Darshan mein BrahmavihÄra BhÄvanÄ, JinÄlaá¹…kÄra, DÄá¹­hÄvaá¹ƒsa, AnÄgatavaá¹ƒsa, ChakesadhÄtuvaá¹ƒsa, PaÃ±cagatidÄ«panÄ«, NÄmarÅ«pasamÄsa, AnagÄrika DharmapÄla: the Revivalist of Buddhism, Gandhavaá¹ƒsa, Bauddha Dharma ke Punaruddharaka: Tripitakacharya Dr. Bhikshu Dharmarakshit, The Revivalist of Buddhism: AnagÄrika DharmapÄla and Saá¹…gharÄja Saraá¹‡aá¹…kara, Human Values and Buddhist Ethics, and NÄmacÄradÄ«paka have been published. He is selected by Department of Higher Education, Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India, New Delhi for the â€˜Presidential Award of Maharshi Badrayan Vyas Sammanâ€™ for the year 2017, and He is honored by Honâ€™ble Vice President of India Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu on 4th April 2019 for the outstanding contribution in the field of PÄli language & literature. In addition to it, his edited & translated book entitled NÄmarÅ«pasamÄsa is selected by Uttar Pradesh Sanskrit Sansthan, Lucknow for the year 2017, and he is also awarded with â€˜Vividh Puraskarâ€™ by Honâ€™ble Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh Shri Yogi Adityanath on 7th February 2018. Currently, he is working as an Assistant Professor in Gautam Buddha University, Greater Noida. His area of interest and research is PÄli language & literature.

table.name: teacherdata
table.column: Digital Signal & Image Processing; Biomedical Instrumentation & Control; Wavelets, AI & Soft Computing Applications to Bio/Renewable Energy and other related areas.

Dr. M. A. Ansari received B.Tech.(1998) in Electrical Engineering from AMU Aligarh, M.Tech.(2001) in Instrumentation & Signal Processing from Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Roorkee and Ph.D. (2009) in the area of Digital Signal & Image Processing from I.I.T. Roorkee.

Dr. Ansari has 20 years of vast experience in teaching, research and industry including 3 years overseas teaching experience. He is currently serving as a senior faculty member & research coordinator in the Dept. of Electrical Engineering, School of Engineering, Gautam Buddha University (GBU), Greater Noida. Previous joining to GBU, he has worked in College of Engineering Roorkee, Galgotias College of Engg. & Technology, Salalah College of Technology, Oman and Faculty of Engineering, Islamic University, Madinah, KSA.

During this period, he has worked at several administrative positions such as Head of the Department, Dean (I/C), Coordinator of International Relations, IEEE Branch Counselor, Coordinator of Alumni Section, Research & Projects, University Admissions and NAAC/NBA accreditation.

Along with teaching responsibilities, he has organized and attended several workshops, seminars, FDPs, STTPs, QIPs, national and International conferences, delivered key notes, invited talks and chaired sessions.

His research interest includes Digital Signal & Image Processing, Medical Image & Video Coding, Biomedical Signal Analysis, Feature Extraction & Image Interpretation,  Biomedical Instrumentation & Control, ANN/Fuzzy/GA/AI Applications to Signal & Image Processing, Wavelets/AI/Soft Computing Applications to Bio/Renewable Energy etc.

He has supervised 8 Ph.Ds, 100 M.Tech. dissertations and 150 B.Tech. projects. He has published more than 175 research papers in reputed National/International Journals/Conferences. He has been contributing as Editor/Reviewer to various Journals/Conferences.

To his credit, he has developed several course curriculums, lab set ups and lab manuals.

Currently, he is senior member of IEEE, IET, IEEE India Council & Computer Society of India. He is life member of ISIAM, ISTE and Alumni Association of AMU Aligarh and I.I.T. Roorkee.

He has been TPC Chair of Nanofim-2017, TPC member of QSHINE2013, ICAEDC-2017, RDCAPE-2017, SPIN- 2018, PEEIC 2018, ICSC 2019, ICMETE2019 and track chair of CCTES-18 and SEEMS 2018. 

He has been given Excellent Teacher award by AHC, India for his dedicated services in teaching & research to the nation, 2018.

table.name: teacherdata
table.column: University School Of Information And Communication Technology
PhD(2014), Computer Science and Technology, Gautam Buddha University, Greater Noida

Dr. Arun Solanki is working as an Assistant Professor in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Gautam Buddha University, Greater Noida, since 2009. He has worked as Time Table Coordinator, member Examination, Admission, Sports Council, Digital Information Cell, and other university teams from time to time. He has received M.Tech. Degree in Computer Engineering from YMCA University, Faridabad, Haryana, India. He has received his Ph.D. in Computer Science and Engineering from  Gautam Buddha University in 2014. He has supervised more than 60 M.Tech. dissertations under his guidance.

His research interests span Expert System, Machine Learning, IoT and Search Engines. He has published many research articles in SCI/ Scopus indexed International journals/conferences like IEEE, Elsevier, Springer, etc. He has participated in many international conferences. He has been a technical and advisory committee member of many conferences. He has organized several FDP, Conferences, Workshops, and Seminars. He has chaired many sessions at International Conferences. Arun Solanki is working as Associate Editor in International Journal of Web-Based Learning and Teaching Technologies (IJWLTT)â€ IGI publisher. He has been working as Guest Editor for special issues in Recent Patents on Computer Science, Bentham Science Publishers. Arun Solanki is the editor of many Books with a reputed publisher like IGI Global, CRC and AAP. He is working as the reviewer in Springer, IGI Global, Elsevier, and other reputed publisher journals.

•        Ph.D. from Gautam Buddha University, Greater Noida, in 2014 with 10 CGPA in course work.
  •        M.Tech. in Computer Science and Engineering from YMCAIE, Faridabad with 1st Division.

• MCA 106 Database Management System
  • IT 206 Database Management System
  • CS 286 Database Management System Lab

My research addresses these and related questions. Research topics that Iâ€™m working on, or have recently worked on, include:

      • Supervised and Unsupervised machine learning techniques.
      • Learning concepts represented by sets of rules.
      • Using probabilistic representations and analyses to address the uncertainty inherent in learning.
      • Automating the process of selecting representations for concepts.
      • Learning several models and combining them to improve accuracy and stability.
      • Evaluating and selecting candidate models to avoid â€œoverfittingâ€ (i.e., to distinguish between genuine regularities and chance occurrences).
      • Learning models that can be easily understood by people.
      • Using pre-existing knowledge to guide and improve learning.
      • Using subsampling techniques to scale up pre-existing approaches.
      • Developing algorithms that take into account the costs of decisions.

PhD ( Ad-hoc wireless networks),M.Tech.( Wireless communication and networks) , B.Tech. (Electronics and communication engineering)
Signal and system, Control theory, Network theory, Ad-hoc wireless networks, Wireless sensor networks etc.

Dr. Vimlesh Kumar Ray is currently faculty in Electronics and Communication Department, School of ICT, Gautam Buddha University.  He has mentored more than 55 M.Tech Dissertation in the field of ad-hoc wireless networks, Wireless sensor networks, cognitive radio technology, intelligent transportation system etc. He has published many research papers in National/ International conferences and Journals. He has guided several projects based on IoT, smart home automation, energy conservation in the networks. He has explored various research and consultants in the area of intelligent transportation system, energy harvesting in ad-hoc / wireless sensor networks, cognitive radio networks, IoT in networks, quality of services (QoS), traffic engineering in wireless networks. He has keen interest in innovation and industrial development projects. He has delivered several invited talks in various FDP/ Workshops.

He has been awarded by Bokaro Steel plant Bokaro for the innovation project. He is national winner of National Children Science Congress. He has been awarded by Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam (Former President of India) and also by Late Sh. Atal Bihari Vajpayee (Former Prime Minister of India) for the innovation project. He has successfully presented the project in Indian Science Congress at Anna University Chennai. He has been also awarded for innovation projects by Bihar Association Chennai and Science for Society Bihar.

Currently i am teaching in Electronics and Communication department, University School of Information and Communication Technology Gautam Buddha University Greater Noida U.P.

table.name: teacherdata
table.column: Dr. Omveer Singh has near about 14 years of teaching as well as research and development experience.  He did his B. Engg. & M. Tech. in Electrical Engineering, and Ph.D degree in Power Systems from Jamia Millia Islamia Univesity (A Central University), New Delhi, India. Currently, he is an Assistant Professor (Senior Scale) in the Department of Electrical Engineering, School of Engineering, Gautam Buddha University (An Uttar Pradesh Government University), Greater Noida, Uttar Pradesh, India. He is a Senior Member of IEEE, and Power & Energy Society of Asia Pacific Region, Member of IAENG Society, Hong Kong, China and Life Member of Institution of Engineers (India). He is also providing voluntary service to several National/International publishing houses as an Editor and Reviewer. He has published over 57 research articles in the peer refereed journals and reputed international/national conferences. He is guiding 04 research scholars and guided many M. Tech. students. He has diversified research interests in the areas of Electrical Power Systems, Renewable Energy Sources, Electric Vehicle, Smart Grid, Soft Computing Techniques and Artificial Intelligent.

table.name: teacherdata
table.column: University School Of Buddhist Studies & Civilization
PhD in Buddhist Studies (2002) from University of Delhi

Dr. Arvind Kumar Singh

Assistant Professor & Head, School of Buddhist Studies & Civilization &

Director, International Affairs

Gautam Buddha University, Greater Noida

Gautam Buddha Nagar, Uttar Pradesh-201312

Email: arvinds@gbu.ac.in & director_ia@gbu.ac.in

arvindbantu@yahoo.co.in and aksinghdu@gmail.com 

Tel: +91-8130117721/8383860546 (M) & +91-120-234-6171/6410

 

 

Arvind Kumar Singh has spent his early life in the spiritual ambiance of Bodh-Gaya (Bihar), the place of the Buddhaâ€™s Enlightenment. Currently he has been teaching in the capacity of Assistant Professor & Head at School of Buddhist Studies and Civilization, and also Director, International Affairs, Gautam Buddha University, Greater Noida, Uttar Pradesh (INDIA). Before joining Gautam Buddha University, he has worked at the Department of Buddhist Studies, University of Delhi for almost six years where he has edited the journal of Department of Buddhist Studies named Buddhist Studies, Volumes XXVIII to XXXIX.  At University of Delhi, he has played an important role in organizing four International and one National Conference of Buddhism apart from inviting Buddhist scholars for special lectures and one day workshops on various aspects of Buddhism. Again at Gautam Buddha University organized two International conference on Introspection on Buddhist Tradition in September 2012 in association with Indian Council for Cultural Relations, New Delhi and Indian Council for Historical Research, New Delhi in which more than 60 International scholars have participated and again in 2017 on Buddhism: Traditions, Ideologies and Dissent in association with ICCR, ICPR, ICSSR, Indo Sri Lanka Foundation, etc.

 

He has written five books on Buddhism, more than 50 research papers published in India and abroad. His area of specializations is Buddhist History (Indian and Abroad), Applied Buddhism, Buddhist Ethics, Engaged Buddhism, Buddhist Personalities, Buddhist Places, etc. He has also presented his research papers on numerous occasions on different aspects of Buddhism from time to time in various seminars and conferences of national and international repute in India and abroad viz. UNDV Conference in Hanoi, Vietnam (2008, 2014 & 2019), UNDV Conference in Bangkok, Thailand from 2009 to 2011, 2015 & 2018, Taiwan in 2011 (December as ICCR Delegate) and Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam in 2013 organized by National University of Vietnam and again 2015 to participate in International conference on Buddhism in Mekong Region organized by Vietnam Buddhist Research Institute and Vietnam Buddhist University at HCM City, Vietnam. Also he has presented a research paper of Buddhism and Peace Conference organized at Sitagu International Buddhist Academy, Sagaing Hills, Mandalay, Myanmar in January 2016 and presented paper at 3rd International Conference of Indologists organized by Indian Council for Cultural Relatuions, MEA, Govt. of India in association with Saint Petersburg State University, Saint Petersburg, Russia in 2018. Recently presented paper at an International Conference on Heritage As Soft Power, organized at University of Kelaniya, Sri Lanka in December 26-27, 2019He was awarded Global Peace Ambassador Award-2017 by International Buddha Education Institute and Youth Action Committee Uttarakhand, Journalist Bimalendu Barua Peace Award-2016 awarded by The World Alliance of Buddhist Leaders & Nirvana Peace Foundation, Bangladesh and Outstanding Peace Activist Award-2016 awarded by International Buddha Education Institute (IBEI) and Younker Scientific and Social Sciences Research Foundation (YSSRF) in recognition of devotion, dedication and commitment towards the development of peace and harmony in the society. Recently, he is appointed Member, Academic Advisory Board of Dhammachai International Research Institute (DIRI), New Zealand and Australia.

table.name: teacherdata
table.column: University School Of Buddhist Studies & Civilization
Buddhist History,Buddhist Art and Architecture,Socially engaged Buddhism

My motto in classroom interactions is inspired by the four pillars of learning introduced in the Delors Commission Report (1996). Accordingly, I will focus more at instigating the inquisition among learners and equip them with as many learning tools and techniques as possible. Buddhist History and its texts demand more reflection and contemplation than any other language and literature. Therefore, I will utilize self-learning and exploration by students. In order to enable the students to express their learning experiences through oral and written presentations; classroom symposiums and workshops can be organized. Outline your most significant contribution to research.Now I have teaching subject given below:

BS-312-an Introductory outline of Buddhist Education System,BS604-Buddhist Ar and Architecture.

Buddhist studies is the most ancient as well as with tremendous scope for Teaching, research and publication in the areas of Pali language, history, art, culture, and philosophy. Research in this area is vital not only for exploring traditional wealth of knowledge and life practices but also the novel dimensions of related to life and beyond life. This will surely add to the wealth of knowledge and add new dimensions to the present as well as future of the country. Our Prime minister also focus on the field of Buddhist culture and Tourism development in India and around the world.I, as a part of GBU  would wish to explore the wider dimensions of Buddhist studies and research by adopting the best practices of the modern learning tools and techniques. The impending generation of Buddhist scholars must understand that they are to play much extensive role not only in their own life but in the lives of their fellow natives as well. Buddhist studies fortunately is most capable in setting right all the odds of the modern world. Therefore, I shall endeavor to explore the much demanded balance between tradition and modernity through knowledge, understanding and application of applied Buddhism.

In my teaching and  research worked  i have focused upon the dichotomy between the higher culture and lower culture.I have thrown light upon the culture of the underprivileged,hitherto neglected,in the context of Buddhist cultural heritage in the  region.The study conducted by the helps in illumination the corridors of regional cultural elements and diversifying the arena of Buddhist heritage in the academic discourse.

I have taught post odd semester-BS101-Human Velue and Buddhist ethics,BS-303-History of India(13th century to 19th century),BS-303-World History,BS-805-An Overview of Buddhism--M.Phil course

• R.B.Singh is working as a Research/Faculty Associate in the Department of Electronics And Communication Engineering, Gautam Buddha University, Greater Noida. He has received M.Tech. Degree in E.C.(VLSI Design) from Nirma University, Ahmedabad , passed in 2008 with first division and B.Tech(Electronics & Telecomm.) from Uttar Pradesh Technical University(U.P.T.U), Lucknow, passed in 2005 with first division.

table.name: teacherdata
table.column: Faculty, Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering
University School Of Information And Communication Technology
Analog and Digital Communication, Microprocessors and Embedded System, Communication Systems

Dr. Sandeep Sharma

Qualification: B.Tech. (ECE), M.Tech. (Digital Communication), PhD.

Teaching Experience:  17 Years

Subjects Taught: Analog Electronics, Digital Electronics, Electronic Devices and Circuits, Analog Communication, Digital Communication Systems, Microprocessors and Interfacing, Design with Microcontrollers, Advanced Digital Communication Systems

Research Area: Security issues in Wireless Sensor Networks, Cross-Layer Design, Wireless Sensor Networks, QoS in Wireless Networks, Wireless Systems.

Interested in: Projects and consultancies in the field of Wireless Systems, Qos in Wireless Sensor Networks, IoT based projects.

M.Tech. Supervision: 65 Students

Area of M.Tech.  Cross-Layer Design, Wireless Sensor localization, Energy-efficient routing protocol design, QoS issues in Wireless Sensor Networks, Wireless Channel Assignment, etc.

Projects guided: Various B.Tech. and M.Tech. Projects based on hardware and software. Such as Smart Helmet, Active noise cancellation, Automatic gate for railways, Patient monitoring system etc.

Dr. Sandeep Sharma

Qualification: B.Tech. (ECE), M.Tech. (Digital Communication), PhD.

• A biography is simply an account of someoneâ€™s life written by another person. A biography can be short in the case of a few sentences biography, and it can also be long enough to fill an entire book. The short biographies explain a personâ€™s basic life facts and their importance, but the long biographies would go an extra mile and include more details to make an interesting read. You may find yourself in a situation which requires you to write a biography of a famous person, a close friend or a relative. For this reason, it pays to know how to come up with a biography and the important details that you should include in it. The lives of many people have interesting bits of information, but you ought to know what to capture in the biography and what to leave out.
  • If your readers don't remember anything else about your bio, make sure they remember your name. For that reason, it's a good idea for your first and last name to be the first two words of your professional bio. Even if your name is printed above this bio (hint: it should), this is a rare moment where it's okay to be redundant.
  • Will your professional bio represent yourself, or a business you work for? Make sure the brand you want to be associated with is mentioned in your bio. If you're a freelancer, perhaps you have a personal business name or pseudonym you advertise to your clients. Here are a few examples:

• #Education:

    The format should be like this

    Degree_Name from College_Name

    Location | Duration(start year-end year) | Percentage

    Summary(short description about what you learned during the course)

    #Achievements

    This section should contain your achievements during the entire academic session.

    Further, you can add Skills, Hobbies, and Interests
